The House passed the bill to address the humanitarian crisis on the border 305-102. 

The bill isn‚Äôt perfect but it helps to solve an immediate need. I am encouraged that, at least today, the House came together in a bipartisan fashion. This is how divided government must work.

I just asked for unanimous consent to bring up the bipartisan Senate bill to address the humanitarian crisis on the border. 

My message to @SpeakerPelosi and @LeaderHoyer: 

Let. Your. Members. Vote. pic.twitter.com/NQYRYcGaFR

This bill passed the Senate 84-8. I have no doubt that it would pass the House with a similar overwhelming majority.

It's time to put people before politics. https://twitter.com/RepArmstrongND/status/1144273616747581442¬†‚Ä¶

It's time to put politics aside and address the crisis on the border.

Gov. @DougBurgum and his fellow GOP governors just sent a letter to Congress urging us to pass #USMCA. 

They're right: Passing USMCA will help American workers reap the benefits of improved trade with Canada & Mexico. 

Read the letter: https://armstrong.house.gov/media/blog-posts/republican-governors-call-congress-pass-usmca¬†‚Ä¶

USMCA updates key provisions of our trading relationship, including fair grading of U.S. wheat, strengthened science-based sanitary and phytosanitary measures, and strong intellectual property and digital products protection.

I got the chance to chat with @CanadianPM @JustinTrudeau last night. We don't agree on much in politics, but we both agree that we need to pass #USMCA. Canada is North Dakota's number one trading partner. ND exports over $4.9 billion annually to our northern neighbors. pic.twitter.com/RqdtTZgjTZ

The Justice Reinvestment Initiative Act will help develop cost-effective, evidence-based solutions to reduce crime and increase public safety while stemming the cost associated with corrections. https://armstrong.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-kelly-armstrong-introduces-justice-reinvestment-initiative-act¬†‚Ä¶

States‚Äô spending on corrections has significantly increased in the past 30 years, from $12B in 1988 to $58B in 2016. These costs are a burden on already overstretched state budgets and divert resources away from other vital services. Read the fact sheets: https://armstrong.house.gov/media/blog-posts/justice-reinvestment-initiative-act¬†‚Ä¶

This is an issue that is very important to me. When I was in the State Senate, I led the Justice Reinvestment Committee, which studied criminal justice reform and helped drive the reforms we put in place in 2015 and 2017. https://bismarcktribune.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/justice-reinvestment-bill-moves-forward/article_f9e2877d-e992-5c30-8869-570e950c02b4.html¬†‚Ä¶

I introduced my first bill today - the Justice Reinvestment Initiative Act. This bill helps state, local, and tribal governments use evidence-based strategies to make communities safer and save money on corrections.  https://armstrong.house.gov/media/press-releases/congressman-kelly-armstrong-introduces-justice-reinvestment-initiative-act¬†‚Ä¶
